title: Unit 0 Diagnostic Checkpoint: Prerequisite Patch
description: Diagnostic checkpoint assessing prerequisite readiness for AP Calculus BC: function composition/inverses, factoring, exponent/log rules, trig fundamentals, and graph interpretation. Identifies specific gaps for targeted repair.

remediationResources.reteachFocus: Composition f(g(x)) — identify outer/inner; inverse functions — swap and solve; (f⁻¹)'(a) = 1/f'(f⁻¹(a))
GCF-first factoring, difference/sum of cubes, rewrite as negative/fractional exponents for power rule, log rules for solving
Unit circle values from memory (no calculator), reference angles by quadrant, Pythagorean identities, solve trig equations on [0,2π)
VA/HA from factoring, symmetric difference quotient for f'(a) from tables, piecewise continuity check, hole vs asymptote

assessmentProblems.question: Given f(x) = x² + 1 and g(x) = 3x − 2, find f(g(x)) and simplify.
Find the inverse of f(x) = (5x + 2)/(x − 3). State any restrictions.
Rewrite in power-rule form and differentiate: f(x) = 5/x² − 3/√x + 2x
Solve: 2ln(x) − ln(x − 3) = ln(4)
assessmentProblems.answer: ln(x²) − ln(x−3) = ln(4) → ln(x²/(x−3)) = ln(4) → x²/(x−3) = 4 → x² = 4x−12 → x²−4x+12 = 0. Discriminant = 16−48 = −32 < 0. No real solution.

assessmentProblems.question: Evaluate without a calculator: sin(5π/6) + cos(7π/4) − tan(π/3)
Solve on [0, 2π): 2cos²x − cosx − 1 = 0
assessmentProblems.answer: Factor: (2cosx + 1)(cosx − 1) = 0. cosx = −1/2 → x = 2π/3, 4π/3. cosx = 1 → x = 0. Solutions: x = 0, 2π/3, 4π/3.

assessmentProblems.question: Find all asymptotes and any holes of f(x) = (x² − 4x + 3)/(x² − 1).
assessmentProblems.answer: Factor: (x−1)(x−3)/[(x−1)(x+1)]. Cancel (x−1) → hole at x = 1: y = (1−3)/(1+1) = −1, hole at (1,−1). Reduced: (x−3)/(x+1). VA: x = −1. HA: y = 1 (equal degrees).

assessmentProblems.question: Given: f(0) = 2, f(1) = 5, f(2) = 11, f(3) = 14, f(4) = 13. Use the symmetric difference quotient to estimate f'(2).
ANALYSIS: A function g is defined by g(x) = { 2x + 1 if x < 2; ax − 3 if x ≥ 2 }. Find the value of a that makes g continuous at x = 2. Justify your answer.
assessmentProblems.answer: For continuity: lim_{x→2⁻} g(x) = lim_{x→2⁺} g(x) = g(2). Left: 2(2)+1 = 5. Right and value: a(2)−3 = 2a−3. Set equal: 2a−3 = 5 → 2a = 8 → a = 4. Justified: with a = 4, both one-sided limits equal 5 = g(2), so g is continuous at x = 2.
